Using the estimator in (20), Sadinle (2017) observes that the LSAP algorithm adopts a conservative approach in declaring links, in that it requires P​(Zj=i|γ)≥.50𝑃subscript𝑍𝑗conditional𝑖𝛾.50P(Z_{j}=i|\gamma)\geq.50.
This reduces the risk of incorrect linkages, but it can introduce bias in the estimation of overlap size under certain linkage scenarios. As an example, consider a task of linking unique individuals in a large data file 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}—which has near complete coverage of a population—to participants in a survey data file ℬℬ\mathcal{B} that overlaps with 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Within 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, suppose exactly two distinct individuals 𝒜1subscript𝒜1\mathcal{A}_{1} and 𝒜2subscript𝒜2\mathcal{A}_{2} share identical names with individual ℬ1∈ℬsubscriptℬ1ℬ\mathcal{B}_{1}\in\mathcal{B}. As a result, the posterior probabilities that Z1=1subscript𝑍11Z_{1}=1 or Zj=2subscript𝑍𝑗2Z_{j}=2 are both near (but necessarily below) 0.50.50.5, as exemplified in Table 1.
In this case, it is reasonable to conclude that one of 𝒜1subscript𝒜1\mathcal{A}_{1} or 𝒜2subscript𝒜2\mathcal{A}_{2} is the true link to ℬ1subscriptℬ1\mathcal{B}_{1}, and therefore to count ℬ1subscriptℬ1\mathcal{B}_{1} as part of the overlap population. However, if we use (20), the BRL estimate fails to declare any links for ℬ1subscriptℬ1\mathcal{B}_{1} in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, even though the chance that
ℬ1subscriptℬ1\mathcal{B}_{1} is not linked to any elements in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is only 2%. Similar issues can arise when more than two records in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} are highly plausible links for some ℬjsubscriptℬ𝑗\mathcal{B}_{j}.

The sufficient condition in (25) assigns a non-link to ℬjsubscriptℬ𝑗\mathcal{B}_{j} when its posterior probability of having no links is largest.
This particular decision rule is reasonable when the posterior distribution for Zjsubscript𝑍𝑗Z_{j} is characterized by large probability mass either at Zj=n𝒜+jsubscript𝑍𝑗subscript𝑛𝒜𝑗Z_{j}=n_{\mathcal{A}}+j or Zj=isubscript𝑍𝑗𝑖Z_{j}=i for some i𝑖i. However, if the posterior distribution is multi-modal across a variety of potential links in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, the sufficient condition may be undesirable. To illustrate, consider the example in Table 2.
According to (25), the LSAP will result in a non-link decision. This results mainly because of significant uncertainty in the match status, as reflected through a posterior distribution with moderate probability masses placed on the decisions Zj=1subscript𝑍𝑗1Z_{j}=1, Zj=2subscript𝑍𝑗2Z_{j}=2, and Zj=n𝒜+jsubscript𝑍𝑗subscript𝑛𝒜𝑗Z_{j}=n_{\mathcal{A}}+j. In a comparison space with multiple instances like the one in Table 2, all would be designated non-links by the LSAP. Such behavior may lead to underestimation of overlap size estimation in practice; for example, in Table 2, the posterior probability of there being a match, 1−P​(Zj=n𝒜+j|γ)1𝑃subscript𝑍𝑗subscript𝑛𝒜conditional𝑗𝛾1-P(Z_{j}=n_{\mathcal{A}}+j|\gamma), is quite high at 70%percent7070\%.

We consider several data scenarios characterized by different overlap sizes and error levels. To facilitate repeated sampling computations, we let n𝒜=1000subscript𝑛𝒜1000n_{\mathcal{A}}=1000 and nℬ=50subscript𝑛ℬ50n_{\mathcal{B}}=50. We determine
the overlap size by setting the proportion π𝜋\pi of records in ℬℬ\mathcal{B} that have links in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} as π∈{25%,50%,75%,100%}𝜋percent25percent50percent75percent100\pi\in\{25\%,50\%,75\%,100\%\}. In each scenario, we generate comparison vectors for F=3𝐹3F=3 binary fields, where γi,j(f)=1superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑖𝑗𝑓1\gamma_{i,j}^{(f)}=1 when 𝒜i,f=ℬj,fsubscript𝒜𝑖𝑓subscriptℬ𝑗𝑓\mathcal{A}_{i,f}=\mathcal{B}_{j,f} and γi,j(f)=2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑖𝑗𝑓2\gamma_{i,j}^{(f)}=2 otherwise. For each field f𝑓f, we set 𝐦f=(mf,1,mf,2)subscript𝐦𝑓subscript𝑚𝑓1subscript𝑚𝑓2\mathbf{m}_{f}=(m_{f,1},m_{f,2})
and 𝐮f=(uf,1,uf,2)subscript𝐮𝑓subscript𝑢𝑓1subscript𝑢𝑓2\mathbf{u}_{f}=(u_{f,1},u_{f,2})
to represent one of three error levels, where smaller values in mf,1subscript𝑚𝑓1{m}_{f,1} accompanied by smaller values in uf,2subscript𝑢𝑓2{u}_{f,2} indicate increased error levels in the linking fields. The parameter settings for each level are displayed in Table 3. These parameter choices are guided by the values of 𝐦fsubscript𝐦𝑓\mathbf{m}_{f} and 𝐮fsubscript𝐮𝑓\mathbf{u}_{f} from the RLdata500 data (Sariyar and
Borg, 2022) that we use in section 4.3.1. Briefly, the low error scenario represents minimal errors across all fields. The moderate and moderate-high error settings represent situations where errors are introduced into two of the three fields to varying extents. When referring to simulation results from the F𝐹F-score point estimator and BRL estimator, we use F-Algo and BRL, respectively.

references: Table 4 displays the simulation results. For each metric, the averages are computed across N=1000𝑁1000N=1000 independent simulation runs to ensure the Monte-Carlo errors remain below 10−6superscript10610^{-6}. At low error levels, the BRL estimator and the F-Algo estimator have comparable efficacy, both in the F𝐹F-scores and overlap size estimates. In scenarios with moderate to moderate-high noise, the F-Algo estimator consistently outperforms the BRL estimator in the sense of higher F𝐹F-scores and more accurate overlap size estimates. In these settings, the BRL estimator is overly conservative. In fact, it often declares all potential pairs as non-links, leading to F𝐹F-scores of zero. Not surprisingly, the absolute performance of both estimators declines as overlap size decreases. With the lowest overlap and at least moderate errors, F-Algo tends to assign too many record pairs as links, whereas BRL tends to declare all record pairs as non-links.

F𝐹F-score Est. Overlap True Overlap Overlap
BRL F-Algo BRL F-Algo 95% CI
Model A 0.71 0.71 32 32 50 (40, 122)
Model B 0.76 0.78 47 52 50 (37, 109)
Model C 0.90 0.90 43 43 50 (43, 58)
Model D 0.98 0.98 51 51 50 (49, 54)
references:
Table 5 displays the results for the RLdata500 illustration.
For Model A, Model C, and Model D, the F𝐹F-score and estimated overlap size for F-Algo and BRL are identical. For model B, the F-Algo estimate has a marginally higher F𝐹F-score than the BRL estimate. In all cases, the estimated overlap size is inside the 95% credible interval. These observations are line with results from the simulation study, where the two estimators offer similar results in the absence of substantial errors in the linking fields.
These results show that directly maximizing the expected F𝐹F-score is compatible with anticipated behavior in these benchmark data.

F𝐹F-score Est. Overlap True Overlap Overlap
BRL F-Algo BRL F-Algo 95% CI
Block 1 Model A 0.87 0.87 154 161 188 (150, 178)
Model B 0.74 0.75 117 138 188 (125, 161)
Block 2 Model A 0.51 0.66 58 88 144 (77, 110)
Model B 0.23 0.57 22 88 144 (59, 99)
references: Table 6 displays the results from the linkage with the Union Army data. In the case of Block 1, the BRL and F-Algo estimates perform similarly, with the same F𝐹F-score for model A and only a marginal difference for model B. For the estimated overlap, the F-Algo estimate is closer to the truth. In the case of Block 2, when there is more ambiguity, the F-Algo estimates have substantially higher F𝐹F-scores than the BRL estimates. Furthermore, the estimated overlaps from the F-Algo estimate are inside the 95% credible intervals, whereas the estimated overlaps for the BRL estimates are not. As seen previously, the F-Algo estimator tends to be less conservative than the BRL estimator in the presence of higher uncertainty, and thus can estimate the number of overlap links more accurately.
